column1: How to control stray dogs has become the most urgent social security issue in the safest country in the world. So
column2: how to control the problem of stray dogs? This has to be said about Germany. The Germans' regulations on raising dogs are really strict and are engraved in the hearts of Germans. Let China copy it
column3: there is indeed something worth learning from capitalism. Here‚Äôs a summary of some of the rules for raising dogs in Germany: 1. Keeping a dog requires the consent of your neighbors. When raising a dog in Germany
column4: you must first obtain the consent of your neighbors and ensure that it will not affect their lives. You can't let your dog urinate randomly
column5: and you can't let your dog bark at home and disturb your neighbors' rest. If you violate these regulations
column6: you may be subject to fines or other penalties. 2. Dog owners and dogs must go to dog school. It costs 50 euros per hour to raise a dog in Germany. After your neighbor agrees
column7: you have to take your puppy to dog school
column8: from kindergarten to junior high school
column9: and then the high school graduation exam. You and you Only when dogs get their diplomas can they enter society. 3. You have to pay tax for raising a dog. You have to pay it every year. Taking Berlin as an example
column10: you need to pay 120 euros in tax every year to raise the first dog
column11: and you have to pay another 180 euros to raise the second dog. If you keep a dog secretly without paying taxes
column12: If found
column13: a fine of 10
column14: 000 euros will be imposed. 4. Dog owners should buy insurance for their dogs. Dog owners should buy insurance for their dogs with a compensation of no less than 1 million euros. Under normal circumstances
column15: German dog owners need to pay an annual insurance premium of 75 to 270 euros for their dogs
column16: and dangerous dogs have to pay more than 30% more premiums. 5. Dog owners must spend enough time with their dogs. When raising a dog in Germany
column17: dog owners need to spend a certain amount of time with their dogs. For example
column18: owners should take their dogs with them when they go out
column19: and they cannot leave their dogs at home alone for more than 3 hours. If you do not walk your dog for a long time
column20: someone will complain to an animal protection organization. The charge is that you torture small animals. 6. Dog owners are fined 90
column21: 000 euros for abandoning dogs. German law stipulates that anyone who abandons a dog (including those who move and leaves the dog in the same place) must be fined 90
column22: 000 euros and may be imprisoned for 3 years. 7. A chip must be implanted and you must pay for it at your own expense. According to the European Union
column23: all pets (cats
column24: dogs
column25: and minks) must have an ID number. There are two options: one is to tattoo the number on a conspicuous part of the pet's skin; the other is to implant it under the skin. Enter the microchip. 8. Adoption costs money. In Germany

column11: Chengdu on Monday (October 16). She is still receiving treatment in the children's ICU. The picture shows the surveillance footage at the time of the incident. (Internet) The Chongzhou City Joint Investigation Team reported on Tuesday (October 17) that the injurious black Rottweiler ran into the community and bit the girl on the morning of the incident. It was captured at about 10 o'clock that night

column31: if a raised animal causes damage to others

column42: Sichuan

column1: Congratulations to my classmate Li Luming for being elected as an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences today. Professor Li Luming has made outstanding contributions in the field of neuromodulation technology. The neuromodulation technology developed by his research team is of great significance for treating neurological diseases and improving human health. Being elected as an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences is an affirmation and recognition of his outstanding achievements in this field. Congratulations again to Professor Li Luming! Professor Li Luming‚Äôs research field is ‚Äúbasic and applied research on active implantable neuromodulation‚Äù. Here is a brief introduction to this field. 1. Review and prospects of active implantable neuromodulation technology Active implantable neuromodulation is a technology that uses implanted electronic devices to perform nerve stimulation
column2: aiming to improve or restore damaged nerve function. This article reviews recent research on active implantable neuromodulation
column3: mainly discusses its application fields
column4: methods and effects
column5: and looks forward to future development directions. Active implantable neuromodulation is widely used in the treatment of various neurological diseases. Research mainly focuses on the treatment of Parkinson's disease
column6: epilepsy
column7: chronic pain and other conditions. Through deep brain stimulation and other means
column8: active implantable neuromodulation technology has become one of the effective methods to treat these diseases. In addition
column9: active implantable neuromodulation technology is also used to improve the motor functions of patients with physical disabilities
column10: as well as to treat mental illness and cognitive impairment. These studies indicate that active implantable neuromodulation technology has broad clinical application prospects. Methods and devices for active implantable neuromodulation technology are constantly being improved and optimized. Research mainly focuses on exploring the relationship between stimulation parameters and neural responses to optimize the effect of neuromodulation. At the same time
column11: new stimulation algorithms and devices are constantly being developed to improve the accuracy and effectiveness of neuromodulation and reduce the risk of side effects and complications. Improvements in these technologies and equipment have provided important support for the further development of active implantable neuromodulation technology. Although active implantable neuromodulation technology has achieved certain success in clinical applications
column12: there are still some challenges and problems that need to be solved. For example
column13: how to improve the accuracy and effect of stimulation
column14: reduce the risk of side effects and complications
column15: and how to achieve multi-channel stimulation and remote monitoring. In addition
column16: the long-term efficacy and safety of this technology also require further evaluation and research. With the advancement of science and technology and the development of medicine
column17: active implantable neuromodulation technology will continue to be in-depth research and improvement. Future research directions include optimizing stimulation algorithms
column18: improving device reliability and safety
column19: and achieving multi-modal regulation. At the same time
column20: with the development of artificial intelligence and machine learning technology
column21: more intelligent and personalized neuromodulation solutions are expected to be realized. In short
column22: active implantable neuromodulation technology is a technology with important clinical application value
column23: and its development will bring revolutionary changes to the treatment of neurological diseases. Although there are still some problems and challenges at present
column24: with the continuous deepening of scientific research and the development of technology
column25: we have reason to believe that this technology will play a greater role in the future and make greater contributions to human health. 2. Classification of basic and applied research on active implantable neuromodulation. According to available references
column26: basic and applied research on active implantable neuromodulation is divided into the following categories: 1. Basic research category: *Study on the electrophysiology of neurons Characteristics and neural network responses
column27: exploring the mechanisms and optimization methods of neural regulation. *Study animal models to provide experimental basis for the clinical application of active implantable neuromodulation technology. 2. Applied research category: *Research on the application of active implantable neuromodulation technology in the treatment of neurological diseases
column28: such as Parkinson's disease
column29: epilepsy
column30: chronic pain
column31: etc. *Research on the application of active implantable neuromodulation technology to improve the motor function of patients with physical disabilities. *Research on the application of active implantable neuromodulation technology in the treatment of mental illness and cognitive impairment. 3. Technology development category: * Research new stimulation algorithms and equipment to improve the accuracy and effect of neural regulation and reduce the risk of side effects and complications. *Research on multi-modal regulation and remote monitoring technologies to achieve more intelligent and personalized neural regulation solutions. By classifying and integrating these reference documents
column32: a clearer understanding of various aspects and development trends of active implantable neuromodulation technology can be obtained. 3. Searched several papers and research results of several overseas scholars in the same field * The role of neural oscillators: Buzs√°ki and Wang‚Äôs paper (2012) discussed the role of neural oscillators in neural regulation and proposed a new type of Neural oscillator circuits designed to simulate the electrophysiological properties of neurons. * Combination and application of brain-computer interface technology: Hampson et al.'s paper (2008) combines brain-computer interface technology with neuromodulation technology and proposes a new brain-computer interface system aimed at helping patients with neurological diseases to exercise Function restored. Wang et al.'s paper (2016) reviewed the application of brain-computer interface technology in neurorehabilitation and discussed future research directions. *Review of neurorehabilitation: The paper by Fiedler et al. (2017) provides a review of neurorehabilitation in patients with spinal cord injury and explores the application of electroencephalography in neuromodulation. *Application of electroencephalogram in neuromodulation: Daly and Wolpaw's paper (2018) reviews the application of electroencephalogram in neuromodulation and discusses its development potential in the field of future neuromodulation. *Other related literature: The remaining papers mainly cover all aspects of active implantable neuromodulation technology
column33: including technology improvement
column34: equipment development
column35: application effect evaluation
column36: etc. These papers provide important reference and support for the further development of active implantable neuromodulation technology. 4. Active Implantable Neuromodulation: Basics

column1: [Large Cap or Small Cap] ‚û§ Small and medium-cap investments have been very popular recently. First

column6: large-cap value investment has always occupied the high ground

column22: second

column41: new

column1: Following the release of a new episode of the Aston Originals podcast
column2: hosted by experts Dr Duane Mellor and Dr Srikanth Bellary
column3: the university‚Äôs diabetes research and how the disease affects communities around Birmingham are discussed. The theme of World Diabetes Day 2023 is getting diabetes care and understanding the risks. Complications of diabetes include circulatory problems
column4: kidney problems and eye damage
column5: and getting the right information and care can significantly reduce your risk. Globally alone
column6: one in 10 people has diabetes
column7: more than 90% of which are type 2 diabetes
column8: half of which are undiagnosed. With treatment and healthy lifestyle habits
column9: people with type 2 diabetes can delay or prevent complications. Experts from Aston University
column10: including Dr Duane Mellor from the School of Medicine and Dr Srikanth Bellary from the School of Biological Sciences
column11: explored risk factors for type 2 diabetes
column12: particularly the prevalence of obesity in deprived areas. People in poor areas often lack opportunities for physical activity and have limited access to healthy foods
column13: which increases the risk of diabetes. Aston University strives to address these social inequalities through research. Although type 2 diabetes is usually associated with older people
column14: an increasing number of younger people
column15: especially those who are obese or from black and South Asian communities
column16: are also being diagnosed with the disease. Dr Bellary is committed to raising awareness of diabetes among young people
column17: particularly among Aston University‚Äôs diverse student body. Advances in blood glucose monitoring technology in recent years have made it easier for patients to manage their diabetes
column18: but digital poverty and access remain issues of concern. Dr. Mellor and Dr. Bellary also believe that artificial intelligence (AI) may play a key role in improving diabetes care in the future. Hide d

column1: According to news on November 20
column2: a joint document seen by Reuters showed that France
column3: Germany
column4: and Italy have reached an agreement on how to regulate artificial intelligence (AI)
column5: which is expected to accelerate negotiations at the European level. The three governments support "mandatory self-regulation" of basic AI models through codes of conduct
column6: but they oppose "untested norms." So-called AI base models are designed to produce a wide range of outputs. France
column7: Germany and Italy said in a joint document: "We jointly emphasize that the AI Act regulates AI applications rather than the technology itself. The inherent risks of AI systems lie in the application rather than the technology." Foreign media expect that Germany
column8: France and Italy will reach an agreement This agreement will accelerate negotiations at the European level and provide a blueprint for European-level AI regulatory guidelines. (Lianhe Zaobao)Collapsed

column1: Bloomberg reports "Altman returns to OpenAI as CEO
column2: former U.S. Treasury Secretary Summers joins board of directors" - This reversal came under intense pressure from OpenAI's big investors - employees threatened to resign if Altman's position was not reinstated. Welcoming Sam Altman back and conducting a major reorganization of the board of directors
column3: introducing new directors including Larry Summers
column4: this change has attracted great attention in Silicon Valley and the global AI circle. Altman will return as CEO
column5: and the new board of directors will be chaired by Bret Taylor
column6: the former co-CEO of Salesforce.com Inc. and a director of Twitter before being acquired by Elon Musk. Other directors include Summers
column7: who served as U.S. Treasury Secretary under President Bill Clinton
column8: and current member Adam D'Angelo
column9: co-founder and CEO of Quora Inc. OpenAI released a statement on X (formerly Twitter)
column10: saying the company is "discussing specific details." After Altman was unexpectedly removed
column11: almost all OpenAI employees threatened to resign
column12: and the company decided to reappoint its co-founder. The decision quickly prompted congratulations from key figures at X
column13: including former president Greg Brockman
column14: who said he would also be returning
column15: as did chief technology officer Mira Murati. Altman was fired on Friday over disagreements with the board over the rapid development and commercialization of artificial intelligence. He has been negotiating with the company for reinstatement. Those talks stalled on Sunday as Altman and others pressured existing board members to resign
column16: according to people familiar with the matter. Ultimately
column17: the board appointed a new leader‚Äîformer Twitch CEO Emmett Shear‚Äîand Microsoft Corp.
column18: OpenAI‚Äôs biggest backer
column19: said it would hire Altman to lead a new internal AI team. In just a few hours
column20: the majority of OpenAI's 770 employees signed a letter to the board of directors saying they might leave to join Microsoft if they didn't all resign and reinstate Altman. Signatories to the letter include Murati
column21: who was named interim CEO
column22: and OpenAI co-founder and board member Ilya Sutskever
column23: who has differences with Altman over the company's direction. Sutskever posted on X (formerly Twitter) on Monday: "I deeply regret participating in the board's decision. I never meant to harm OpenAI. I love everything we have created together and will do my best to restore unity to the company." Altman The return caps a tumultuous past few days that have plunged the world's best-known AI startup into chaos. Summers is a Harvard professor and a staff writer for Bloomberg Television who also serves on the boards of Jack Dorsey's Block Inc. and Skillsoft Corp. This swift policy reversal may appease investors and reduce the risk of employee exodus en masse. However
column24: it also raises questions about the future path for ChatGPT‚Äôs makers and other AI startups. These companies have struggled to find a balance between developing artificial intelligence responsibly while raising huge sums of money from investors to support the expensive computing infrastructure required to build these tools. OpenAI was founded in 2015 as a non-profit organization whose purpose is to promote the development of artificial intelligence (AI) and aim to benefit mankind rather than pursue financial gain. The organization later transformed into a profit-cap company and raised billions of dollars from Microsoft and other investors. Although Altman played a major role in these transactions
column25: OpenAI is still governed by a nonprofit board of directors. In recent days
column26: this internal tension has intensified and become the focus of public attention. News of Altman's removal caught the startup's investors off guard. Microsoft
column27: one of the major backers that invested more than $10 billion in the startup
column28: was notified only minutes before Altman was fired. The software giant then began working with investors including Thrive Capital and Tiger Global Management to try to bring Altman back. People familiar with the matter said they wished to discuss the private information anonymously. But when that effort failed
column29: Microsoft decided to hire Altman and others from OpenAI. Meanwhile
column30: OpenAI faces a new uncertainty: whether to let employees sell their shares at a valuation of $86 billion. Thrive
column31: which is expected to lead the employee stock tender offer
column32: had not paid as of Saturday and told OpenAI that Altman's departure would affect its decision-making
column33: people familiar with the matter said. Among all the figures
column34: the 38-year-old Altman has become the spokesperson of artificial intelligence technology in the new era with the success and popularity of ChatGPT. This year
column35: Altman has not only been actively working with regulators within the industry
column36: but has also met regularly with world leaders
column37: including U.S. President Joe Biden and British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak. On Thursday
column38: he also participated in an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation panel discussion with other executives and world leaders to discuss the future of AI and its risks. But behind the scenes
column39: conflicts between Altman and board members escalated
column40: particularly with Sutskever. They disagree on how to quickly develop generative AI

column1: Parkinson's disease is a chronic neurological disease first described by British physician James Parkinson in 1817. It usually develops in age 50 and later
column2: and its incidence increases with age. The cause of Parkinson's disease is not fully understood
column3: but may be related to factors such as environment
column4: genetics and aging of the nervous system. The main symptoms of Parkinson's disease include resting tremor
column5: bradykinesia
column6: muscle stiffness
column7: and postural balance disorders. Parkinson's disease affects patients' health in many ways. First of all
column8: from a psychological perspective
column9: patients with Parkinson's disease often suffer from depression
column10: anxiety and other psychological problems. This is mainly due to the physiological impact of the disease itself and the psychological pressure on patients when facing the disease. Secondly
column11: in terms of movement
column12: Parkinson's disease can cause muscle stiffness and bradykinesia
column13: which in turn affects the patient's walking
column14: coordination and balance abilities. In addition
column15: sensory aspects can also be affected. For example
column16: some people with Parkinson's disease may experience symptoms such as loss of smell and reduced pain perception. In terms of diet
column17: patients with Parkinson's disease may have problems such as difficulty swallowing and oral muscle incoordination
column18: which may lead to difficulty eating and choking. Finally
column19: Parkinson's disease can also affect a patient's sleep. Many patients will suffer from insomnia
column20: night awakenings and other problems
column21: which will undoubtedly greatly reduce their quality of life. In addition
column22: with the development of artificial intelligence and machine learning technology
column23: we may also see the emergence of more intelligent medical devices and treatments
column24: which will bring more treatment options and hope to patients with Parkinson's disease. Traditional Chinese medicine and Western medicine have their own advantages and disadvantages in the treatment of Parkinson's disease. The advantages of traditional Chinese medicine in treating Parkinson's disease include small side effects
column25: good overall regulatory effect
column26: and the ability to improve patients' clinical symptoms and quality of life. The advantage of Western medicine in treating Parkinson's disease is that it has a rapid onset of action and obvious effects
column27: but it has large side effects and high risks of surgical treatment. ÓòßParkinsonÓòßDr. Wang ShilongÓòßTraditional Chinese MedicineCollapse d

column1: Some institutions predict that the global economy will continue to decline in 2024 and may encounter challenges far greater than this year. On the one hand
column2: interest rate hikes and geopolitical risks have had a huge impact on the global economy
column3: leading to slower economic growth
column4: rising inflation
column5: intensified debt crises
column6: and increased social instability. On the other hand
column7: the development of the digital economy
column8: low-carbon economy and regional value chains has brought new impetus to the global economy
column9: promoted the optimization of the economic structure
column10: and created new business models and employment opportunities. In such a turbulent era
column11: the trend of the global economy will depend on how governments and central banks respond to crises and seize opportunities. How to coordinate interests? First
column12: the growth rate of the global economy in 2024 will be slower than in 2023
column13: but will still remain at a relatively moderate level. It is predicted that the global GDP growth rate will drop slightly to 2.8% in 2024 from about 3% in 2023. This is mainly due to the following four reasons: 1. Geographical risks have caused supply shocks to the global economy
column14: causing economic activities to not fully return to normal levels
column15: but to remain in an inefficient state. For example
column16: frictions between Russia and Ukraine and conflicts between Palestine and Israel have brought uncertainty and disruption to global energy supply and trade. 2. The aging of the population in major economies around the world is becoming more and more serious
column17: resulting in a reduction in labor supply and a decline in potential growth rate. For example
column18: the Eurozone has a much older population than the United States
column19: making its economic growth slower and sluggish. 3. In order to control inflation
column20: major central banks around the world continue to raise interest rates and tighten monetary policies
column21: leading to a contraction in credit and a drag on economic growth. For example
column22: the Federal Reserve raised interest rates four times in 2023 and is expected to raise interest rates twice more in 2024
column23: which will increase the real interest rate level in the United States and have a suppressive effect on investment and consumption. 4. Although global trade conditions will improve in 2024 as the global supply chain is repaired
column24: global trade growth will still be difficult to return to normal levels because global trade protectionism and unilateralism still exist
column25: and global trade rules and order remain. Unstable. For example
column26: the trade friction between the United States and China has not been fundamentally resolved
column27: and the trade dispute between the United States and the European Union has not been properly handled. Secondly
column28: the global economic environment in 2024 will be very sensitive and easily affected by uncertain events. On the one hand
column29: the slowdown in economic growth will inevitably be accompanied by an intensification of the game of interests. Competition and conflicts among countries will become more intense
column30: and global governance and cooperation will become more difficult. For example
column31: the United States will usher in a presidential election in 2024
column32: which will affect the domestic and foreign policies of the United States
column33: as well as the global political and economic landscape. On the other hand
column35: the relationship between global inflation and employment will undergo major changes
column36: which will affect the policy orientation and market expectations of major global central banks. In 2024
column37: the relationship between global inflation and employment will slip from the steepest part to the concave part. This means that in order to reduce inflation
column38: more employment will need to be sacrificed
column39: unemployment will rise
column40: and economic growth will slow down. This will force the world's major central banks to shift from focusing on inflation to focusing on employment
column41: from tightening policy to easing policy
column42: and from hawkish to dovish. This policy shift will lead to increased market sensitivity to macro policies and increased financial market volatility. For example
column43: if the Fed's policy changes are less than market expectations
column44: U.S. bond yields and the U.S. dollar exchange rate may fluctuate significantly
column45: which will have an impact on global asset prices. In addition
column46: the structure of the global economy will undergo profound changes in 2024
column47: which will bring new risks and opportunities to the global economy. On the one hand
column48: risk factors still exist and require vigilance and prevention. For example
column49: the debt levels of some countries around the world are too high
column50: and the risk of debt crisis is still high. Especially in the context of rising global interest rates
column51: debt repayment pressure will increase. At the same time
column52: some major emerging market countries will face structural challenges in the labor market
column53: including population aging
column54: skills shortages
column55: and rising unemployment
column56: which will affect the quality and efficiency of economic growth
column57: as well as social stability and harmony. On the other hand
column58: opportunities are also emerging that need to be seized and exploited. For example
column59: the development of digital economy and low-carbon economy will provide new impetus for global economic growth
column60: promote the optimization of economic structure
column61: and create new business models and employment opportunities. In 2024
column62: major breakthroughs will be made in the fields of artificial intelligence
column63: renewable energy
column64: and environmental protection technology
column65: which will accelerate the application of artificial intelligence in various industries
column66: improve energy utilization efficiency
column67: and reduce environmental pollution. In addition
column68: the reorganization of global supply chains will also bring new opportunities to the global economy. Due to the intensification of geopolitical risks
column69: the global regional value chain system is taking shape
column70: and more companies will re-evaluate their supply chain strategies to adapt to the new geopolitical landscape and economic competition environment. This will promote intra-regional trade and investment and improve The level of economic integration within the region. To sum up
column71: the global economy in 2024 will show three major characteristics: "slow growth
column72: high sensitivity
column73: and deep transformation." This is an era of both tests and opportunities for governments and central banks of all countries. For those who are unintentional
column74: this means dangers abound; for those who are prepared
column75: it means endless opportunities. What do you think of it? Hide d

column1: Life is education
column2: and family is school. Education expert Professor Zhu Yongxin once said: "Almost all excellent children have the imprint of their parents; in all problem children
column3: the reasons for their families can also be found." Family education is the foundation of the entire education chain. If a child's growth goes awry or there are problems with his upbringing
column4: the parents are naturally to blame. Today
column5: we take a closer look at 9 common misunderstandings in today‚Äôs family education to see if you have fallen into any of them. There is only tame education but no personality education. China Youth Daily conducted a survey on 2
column6: 000 teenagers and found that 48.4% of the children suffered from "supporting role syndrome." Most of the interviewees admitted that the education they received since childhood was to "be a good child"
column7: and they have become more and more obedient as their parents wanted. But as they grow up
column8: they gradually lose their edges and individuality
column9: lack self-confidence
column10: and lose the ability to question and imagine. German psychologist Heicha once followed and observed 100 children who dared to question authority and 100 well-behaved and obedient children. Ultimately
column11: it was found that 84% of the former were strong-willed and had the ability to independently analyze
column12: judge things and make decisions when they grew up; while most of the latter became submissive and fearful of taking responsibility. Zhang Tongdao
column13: director of the documentary "Post Zero"
column14: said: "There are no two identical leaves in this world. Respecting the individuality of each child is the starting point of education." A child whose personality has been smoothed out is destined to become more mediocre as he lives. Because edges and corners are often where a person‚Äôs brilliance lies. There is only talent education but no personality education. In the popular drama "The Hidden Corner"
column15: Zhu Chaoyang is a recognized academic master. He ranks first in the grade every year
column16: but he cannot get along with his classmates because of his dull personality. The head teacher came to his mother to discuss the matter
column17: but his mother said: "Students should focus on studying. Making friends is something you do when you enter society. Just study well and everything else is not important." In daily life
column18: The topics she communicated with her son were limited to homework and scores. It was precisely because of the mother's neglect of her son's character development that Chaoyang embarked on the path of darkness step by step
column19: and eventually became a cold
column20: dark
column21: and lying little devil. Li Meijin
column22: an expert in educational psychology
column23: has emphasized more than once: Children‚Äôs character development is more important than intellectual education. The ultimate goal of education is not that everyone becomes a talent
column24: but that everyone becomes an adult. As Professor Yi Zhongtian said: "My slogan is
column25: I hope my children will grow up. What kind of person? A real person. Is there a standard? Yes
column26: eight words: first truth
column27: second kindness
column28: third health
column29: fourth happiness." Only There is no quality education in exam-oriented education. After this year‚Äôs college entrance examination results were released
column30: one comment left a deep impression on me: ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs super academics are no longer stereotyped nerds
column31: but are sunny
column32: confident
column33: cheerful
column34: courageous
column35: dreamy
column36: and dare to All-round talents who challenge and reject mediocrity and give full play to the color of youth..." Indeed
column37: today's top academics not only have excellent academic performance
column38: but also all have talents. But if you observe carefully
column39: you will find that the parents of these top academics often have similar educational philosophies: rather than test-taking ability
column40: they care more about whether their children have self-learning ability
column41: hobbies
column42: and a strong heart. Therefore
column43: the parents of Wu Yishu
column44: a talented poet and poet
column45: will cultivate the habit of reading in their daughter from an early age. They will read "Strange Stories from a Chinese Studio" and then "A Dream of Red Mansions" with their daughter; the parents of Meng Linghao
column46: a top student in Shandong 711
column47: will not force him to He attends tutoring classes and fully supports his son‚Äôs hobby of playing the cello. As Tang Jiangpeng
column48: vice president of the Chinese Education Society
column49: said: "Without scores
column50: students cannot pass today's college entrance examination; but with only scores
column51: I am afraid they will not be able to win future major exams." In the second half of life
column52: what widens the gap between children is not IQ is not a score
column53: but the cultivation of interests
column54: the shaping of habits
column55: the development of mentality... These comprehensive qualities are the core competitiveness of children in the future. There is only elite education but no spiritual education. Former Peking University psychiatrist Xu Kaiwen told a case: There is a child whose parents are bankers and live a wealthy life. He is also in high school in an international school and studies very hard. How hard have you worked? Since I was in junior high school
column56: I have been studying later and later every day
column57: at twelve o'clock
column58: one o'clock
column59: two o'clock... By the second semester of my sophomore year in high school
column60: I had to stay up until three or four o'clock every night. Under the pressure
column61: the child began to harm himself and even had suicidal thoughts. Dr. Xu suggested sending the child to the hospital for treatment
column62: but only two days later
column63: the parents discharged the child. When I asked
column64: my parents said it was time for the final exam. The child also said that he must keep the first place
column65: otherwise there will be nothing. Unexpectedly
column66: two weeks later
column67: the child's mother called Dr. Xu and said that the child had used the chemistry knowledge she had learned to end his own life. A child is not a learning machine
column68: and the meaning of parents to their children is not just to urge them to become elites. Rather than teaching children to work hard to win
column69: what children need more is someone telling them how to embrace failure. After all
column70: on the road of life
column71: there are times of clear skies and times of wind and rain. Real strength does not mean that you have never experienced the ravages of wind and rain
column72: but that you can withstand it no matter how strong the wind is or how heavy the rain is. Turn the wounds you have suffered into your own unique medals. There is only short-sighted education and no competitive education. At the beginning of this year
column73: "ChatGPT" came out. After talking to experts and conducting research
column74: the media website Insider compiled a list of the types of jobs with the highest risk of being replaced by artificial intelligence technology. Although the span of these occupations is large
column75: they have several obvious common characteristics: they either do not require much creativity and do not need to overthink when operating
column76: or the work content is relatively solid and highly repetitive. This also reminds us that with the development and improvement of artificial intelligence
column77: parents must also adjust their education strategies in a timely manner. If you only focus on the current utility
column78: blindly force your children to answer questions
column79: take exams
column80: or improve their academic performance
column81: and ignore the prediction of future development
column82: your children will completely lose their competitiveness in ten years. Parents love their children and have far-reaching plans. What we should really focus on is not children‚Äôs recitation and problem-solving abilities
column83: but those abilities that are scarce in artificial intelligence. For example
column84: higher emotional intelligence
column85: a strong heart
column86: literary and artistic accomplishments
column87: emotional and relationship processing abilities
column88: etc. Education is not for temporary leadership
column89: but a far-sighted investment. By continuing to learn and empower children
column90: they can find opportunities to embrace the future amid tremendous changes. There is only success education but no adult education. Nan Huaijin
column91: a master of Chinese studies
column92: once said a shocking saying: "Don't think that getting a university diploma or a doctorate is enough to be great. This is not considered success. You must know that the purpose of education is to be a successful person." We have always emphasized the importance of success to our children. But in fact
column93: if a child does not know how to behave
column94: no matter how capable he is
column95: he will be rejected by others. There is such a story: a child studying in Germany had excellent grades in school
column96: but was repeatedly rejected when looking for a job after graduation. After one interview
column97: he couldn't bear it anymore and asked the interviewer face to face why he was not hired. The interviewer said frankly: "We highly recognize your work ability
column98: but we checked your credit record and found that you have experienced fare evasion three times. Therefore
column99: we unanimously believe that you do not follow the rules and are not worthy of trust." From a long life perspective
column100: character is the most decisive quality. No matter how outstanding your achievements are
column101: you will not be able to be entrusted with important tasks if you have bad conduct; no matter how outstanding your abilities are
column102: you will not be able to go far if you don't know how to behave. If you don‚Äôt want to work hard all your life and raise a waste that cannot adapt to society
column103: you must tell your children as early as possible: Talent is very important in this life
column104: but altruistic thinking and a down-to-earth life are more important. There is only utilitarian education but no emotional education. Qian Liqun
column107: including the best Peking University and Tsinghua University
column108: there are a group of students in their 20s who are already "sophisticated" students. They are highly intelligent
column113: and are better at using the system to achieve their own goals. He called this group of people "refined egoists." Such children are often the product of utilitarian education. The writer Jiu Ye knew a teacher couple who worked hard to train their son to become an elite. After the son took root in Germany
column114: the couple spent all their savings to help their son buy a house abroad. But when his father was diagnosed with cancer
column115: his son only came back for two days in a hurry
column116: during which time he was still dealing with official duties. Until his father became seriously ill and passed away
column117: his son never came home to see him again. Suddenly one day
column118: the son heard that the house in his hometown was going to be demolished
column119: so he took his wife and daughter back to China and asked his mother for compensation. The old mother
column121: regretted it endlessly. She had only taught her children to strive for first place
column122: but failed to teach them to love
column123: and ultimately ended up living a miserable life. As the writer Bi Shumin said: "Parents in the world
column125: you must let them start to love you and the people around you from the moment they can. This is by no means selfishness of adults
column126: but the foresight of thinking for the whole life of your children." Teaching children to express love and give love is more important than letting them strive for first place and go to a prestigious school. With only fraction education and no life education
column127: do you know how to easily raise a child to waste? That is to let the child have a superior status in the family
column129: and doing everything for him like a nanny. Educator Suhomlinsky once warned parents: "Don't protect your children from working
column130: and don't be afraid that your children's hands will wear calluses. Let your children know that bread is hard-won. This kind of labor is very important to your children." It is said to be true joy." Life is education
column131: and family is school. On weekdays
column132: we can let children clean up their toys by themselves
column133: so that they can learn to arrange space reasonably and be responsible for their belongings; or we can let children go into the kitchen more
column134: so that they can understand the ratio of ingredients and condiments
column137: and It can also improve the coordination ability of the brain; it can also let children wash clothes and clean the room by themselves
column138: so as to appreciate the hard work and dedication of their parents... It is better to let children understand the meaning of responsibility and independence in the process of sweating. the value of. There is only moral education without rules education. This summer
column140: Guangdong: 12-year-old boy Xiao Du went to the beach to play with two friends. One of his companions accidentally fell into the water. Xiao Du
column141: who was eager to save people
column142: stretched out his arms desperately. He took action
column143: trying to grab his companion. However
column144: because his own strength was too weak
column145: he also fell into the sea and was rescued by his companions who fell into the water. Xiao Du disappeared into the vast sea. Similar stories happen every year: In Tongnan District
column147: 8 children went to the river to play in the water. One child lost his footing and fell into the river. The other 7 children went to rescue them one by one
column148: but they were all drowned by the turbulent river water. Swallowed; in Xiamen
column150: several teenagers went to the beach to play together. One of them fell into deep water
column151: and the other two tried to save him. In the end
column152: a rescuer drowned together with the person who fell into the water... There are no ifs in life
column153: but tragedy requires Reflect. For a long time
column154: our education has always been habitual to instill in children the concept of self-sacrifice and selfless sacrifice
column155: and blindly requires children to be kind and brave. But few people tell their children about the rules of life: when you are weak and encounter an emergency
column156: you don‚Äôt have to be so "kind". Do your best to ensure your own safety first
column157: and then call for help from the adults around you or call the police; when facing bad people
column159: you don't have to be completely "honest"
column160: you can choose to lie to ensure your personal safety... It is certainly important to cultivate children's sense of morality
column161: but the rules about life safety must also be instilled in time. I hope you can collect the above nine reflections on Chinese family education and reflect on yourself at any time. Don't let wrong educational concepts delay your child's future. Hide d

column1: The latest update is here. Sam is negotiating with the board of directors and feels that the possibility of return is relatively high. Key points: -Sam Altman is currently discussing a possible return with the OpenAI board of directors. He especially communicated with Adam D'Angelo (CEO of POE). -One of the options is to establish a transitional board of directors with Sam as director. - OpenAI‚Äôs new CEO Emmett Shear revealed to relevant sources that if the board of directors cannot provide sufficient evidence
column2: he will choose to leave his post. The following is a report from Bloomberg: Sam Altman has opened negotiations with the OpenAI board to explore his possible return - the negotiations focus on whether Altman can return as CEO - current CEO Emmett Shear asked the board to provide evidence of Altman's misconduct. According to people familiar with the matter
column3: Sam Altman
column4: part of OpenAI Board members and the company's interim CEO have begun talks to consider bringing the ousted CEO back to the artificial intelligence startup he co-founded. The negotiations were between Altman
column5: CEO Emmett Shear and at least one board member
column6: Adam D'Angelo. People familiar with the matter said they chose to remain anonymous because the discussions were private and could end in nothing. The talks also involve some of OpenAI's investors
column7: many of whom are actively pushing for Altman's return. A person familiar with the matter said that if Altman does return
column8: he will serve as the company's CEO. One possibility currently being discussed is that Altman would serve on a transitional board. At the same time
column9: according to multiple people familiar with the matter
column10: former Salesforce Inc. co-CEO Bret Taylor may also serve as a director on the new board of directors. The board's communication with Altman was an important development because until Monday
column11: directors had largely refused to engage with the executive they fired on Friday
column12: according to several people familiar with the matter. According to Bloomberg

column14: Khosla Ventures and Tiger Global Management. Sequoia Capital
column15: a well-known venture capital firm
column16: is acting in concert with these shareholders

column18: Anna Makanju

column21: Altman and Shear to reach consensus. Previously
column22: most employees had threatened to resign en masse if Altman was not reappointed
column23: among other demands. More details: OpenAI leadership tells employees to 'move on' amid chaos Addressing the company's leadership turmoil before Thanksgiving is an urgent priority
column24: a person familiar with the matter said

column26: which claimed the CEO was "not always honest" in his communications. Since then

column28: " leaving an information void. As the CEO of Microsoft Corp.
column29: OpenAI‚Äôs largest investor

column31: which will greatly enhance Microsoft's strategic position
column32: especially if Microsoft can have a seat on the new board of directors. This may also be an outcome that Microsoft would prefer to see

column1: OpenAI's "Palace Change" in the past two days has triggered a big discussion on "how artificial intelligence should develop". Should the development of artificial intelligence be restricted and only allowed to become an auxiliary tool for humans? Or should it be allowed to develop? Let it become a human-level existence
column2: or even surpass human beings (it can do everything instead of human beings)? \r\n\r\nThe self-driving car accident that occurred in the United States in October can give us some hints. On October 2
column3: a human-driven car hit a pedestrian in San Francisco
column4: USA. It was not a big deal
column5: and the pedestrian who was hit was not seriously injured. However
column6: after the pedestrian was hit
column7: he fell under a self-driving car; the self-driving car started to park to the right according to the intelligent principle of "pull over after a collision to minimize safety risks"; this caused the pedestrian below to
column8: was dragged 6 meters by the self-driving car
column9: crushed and hit
column10: and his injuries became serious. \r\n\r\nLogically speaking
column11: there is nothing wrong with pulling over after a collision. However
column12: the autonomous driving system did not take into account various special situations (such as this time
column13: there was a person under the wheel)
column14: which led to disaster. Of course
column15: you can say that the autonomous driving system is not mature enough yet
column16: and it will be perfect after taking into account various special circumstances. \r\n\r\nHowever
column17: what I want to remind you is: the core of this matter is not that the autonomous driving is not perfect
column18: but that the autonomous driving system can completely reject human intervention and make its own judgments. If autonomous driving is controlled by some bad capital
column19: the people riding on autonomous driving and the city streets where autonomous driving is rampant will become prey for others; if autonomous driving derives autonomous consciousness
column20: it can even oppose AI. Engineers modified it. \r\n\r\nSo
column21: my personal point of view is: the development direction of artificial intelligence must be to "let it become a high-level assistant to human beings"
column22: and it must be left in the artificial intelligence backend port that humans can intervene at any time. Highest authority. \r\n\r\nTo use a sentence from the famous science fiction book "The Three-Body Problem": We must give civilization to technology
column23: rather than giving technology to civilization. Hide d

column1: From Bloomberg: There are not many details about the interpretation of the future battle of OpenAI
column2: but it talks about the background of the whole thing in general
column3: and specifically mentions China‚Äôs investment and work results in AI that are eye-catching. ‚Äî‚ÄîInterpretation of the battle for the future of OpenAI - Sam Altman's sudden dismissal triggered chaos in the startup company - Almost all employees are currently threatening to leave the company OpenAI
column4: as the developer of ChatGPT
column5: fired its co-founder and co-founder last Friday. CEO Sam Altman caused a huge controversy. This shocking news has unsettled investors
column6: partners and employees
column7: and also made this start-up company at the forefront of the world's artificial intelligence field face severe challenges. Summary of key information: Why is OpenAI so critical? The San Francisco-based company launched ChatGPT a year ago
column8: and the AI chatbot now has 100 million weekly users. The great success of ChatGPT not only triggered a large-scale investment trend in generative AI
column9: but also pushed artificial intelligence into the public eye. OpenAI‚Äôs technology has also become the benchmark for many competing AI companies around the world. In the days before Altman's departure
column10: OpenAI's valuation reached about $86 billion in an equity transfer that was about to be completed. Now the fate of this equity transfer is in jeopardy. OpenAI's close relationship with Microsoft Corp.
column11: which owns about 49% of OpenAI and is its main provider of computing power
column12: further enhances the startup's standing in the industry. Affected by the turmoil in OpenAI's leadership
column13: Microsoft's stock price has also fluctuated. What‚Äôs happening with OpenAI recently? On Friday
column14: OpenAI's board issued a cryptic statement
column15: saying Altman was fired because he "was not always candid in his communications with the board." Another co-founder
column16: Greg Brockman
column17: was demoted from the board and quit in protest. The pair tried to negotiate a return to OpenAI on Sunday
column18: with one condition being that existing board members be replaced. Meanwhile
column19: OpenAI's investors and top executives are pushing for Altman's reappointment. However
column20: OpenAI's board of directors eventually appointed Twitch co-founder and former CEO Emmett Shear as the second interim CEO. The previous interim CEO-Chief Technology Officer Mira Murati-supported the return of Altman and Brockman to the company. Later
column21: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella announced that Altman and Brockman would lead a new AI research group within the $2.8 trillion software company. After this
column22: almost all OpenAI employees threatened to leave and join Microsoft unless Altman was reappointed and the entire board of directors resigned. What do the two opposing sides pursue? Altman has been a leading figure at OpenAI
column23: transforming the company from a nonprofit into a globally recognized AI research brand. But he and board members disagreed over steps to rapidly develop generative AI
column24: how to commercialize the product and how to reduce potential harm to the public. So far
column25: the board of directors has given no further public explanation for Altman's departure. For Microsoft
column26: OpenAI is the core of its AI strategy. Nadella showed that whether Altman and his team return to Microsoft or OpenAI
column27: he will be fine with it. The key is to maintain the expertise and research power they had last week. In addition
column28: companies such as Nvidia Corp. and Salesforce Inc. have expressed willingness to hire OpenAI software engineers. After Nvidia's high-standard accelerator chips
column29: AI talent is the industry's scarcest resource. Why do some people think OpenAI‚Äôs technology may be dangerous? This is in line with widespread concerns about the threats that AI may pose. There are concerns that rapid development of AI without adequate human supervision may produce uncontrolled intelligence. While this theoretical scenario may be some time away
column30: efforts are still underway to understand the full impact that intelligent computers could have
column31: including augmenting or replacing jobs
column32: accurately predicting the future
column33: and simulating human reasoning and conversation. How does the turmoil at OpenAI reflect the broader discussion about AI? While we haven't yet gotten a full explanation for the board's firing of Altman
column34: the dispute over the speed of commercialization appears to be the key. This divide is reflected in other areas as well. For example
column35: Google has always advocated a cautious and slow-moving strategy
column36: which made it seem slightly behind OpenAI after it launched ChatGPT and quickly became popular. Although Google has invested more than ten years of research and investment in the field of AI. With labels like ‚Äúaccelerationist‚Äù and ‚Äúsafetyist‚Äù emerging
column37: lines have been drawn around levels of optimism about AI‚Äôs potential benefits and risks. Some accelerationists argue that the United States must act as quickly as possible in order not to be overtaken by China. Google CEO Sundar Pichai also said that China‚Äôs investment and work results in AI are impressive. Google‚Äôs Pichai thinks China will be at the forefront of AI (1) O web link Why do people want Altman to return to OpenAI? Altman played a key role in raising OpenAI's profile and securing a multibillion-dollar deal with Microsoft that provided the company with the technology resources it needed. His experience at the startup accelerator YCombinator and his interactions with the Silicon Valley venture capital circle make him well-suited to lead the company in seeking additional investment and support. The $86 billion equity transfer
column38: led by Thrive Capital
column39: has not been completely canceled
column40: but now appears to depend on Altman's return and OpenAI returning to its status quo before last week's changes. What is the future direction of artificial intelligence? This emerging technology is undergoing regulatory scrutiny and assessment globally
column41: with the UK recently organizing an international conference to discuss appropriate strategies for its adoption. Private companies and government agencies are negotiating how to mitigate potential harm without stifling innovation. In China
column42: Beijing has also taken the lead in formulating a series of clear regulations on the use of AI
column43: taking into account the benefits and competitive advantages brought by leadership in the technological field. In terms of the development and application of AI
column44: the current focus of most people is to obtain as much computing power as possible to train large-scale basic models. The next focus will be on model optimization and specialization. Before last week's chaos

column1: Zhong Zhengsheng: Can the "re-industrialization" of the United States break through under the Biden era? Author: Zhong Zhengsheng
column2: Fan Chengkai (Zhong Zhengsheng is a director of the China Chief Economist Forum and chief economist of Ping An Securities) Core Points Biden‚Äôs ‚Äúre-industrialization‚Äù is beginning to show results. Since 2021
column3: the Biden administration has sounded the clarion call for "Reindustrialization 3.0" and launched the largest public investment plan since Roosevelt's New Deal
column4: focusing on the "American Rescue Plan" (ARP) and the "Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act" ( IIJA)
column5: the Chip and Science Act (CHIPS) and the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). Investment plans related to the "re-industrialization" theme total approximately US$1.2 trillion
column6: which are planned to be invested in the next 5-10 years
column7: with the peak expenditure likely to be in 2024-2027. How to understand Biden‚Äôs vision of ‚Äúreindustrialization‚Äù? First
column8: Biden's "re-industrialization" inherits the goals of the Obama era and has become a consensus between the two parties now; second
column9: the impact of the new crown has strengthened the Biden administration's focus on infrastructure and industrial chain security; finally
column10: in the context of the game between great powers
column11: There is greater urgency for the United States to revive its manufacturing industry. So far
column12: the initial results of Biden's "re-industrialization" are as follows: 1) manufacturing employment has recovered rapidly and exceeded the pre-COVID-19 level; 2) demand for goods has driven a recovery in the proportion of manufacturing added value in GDP
column13: and the economic structure has been optimized; 3) Non-residential construction investment has increased significantly
column14: mainly driven by the infrastructure field and the computer
column15: electronics and electrical industries; 4) Capital expenditures (CAPEX) of U.S. listed companies have increased significantly; 5) FDI inflows into the U.S. manufacturing industry have accelerated
column16: etc. New opportunities for America‚Äôs ‚Äúreindustrialization.‚Äù The U.S. has made limited progress in revitalizing its manufacturing industry over the past decade due to a variety of reasons - declining consumer demand for goods relative to services
column17: lack of coherence in industrial policy
column18: labor cost disadvantages
column19: and the negative impact of the appreciation of the U.S. dollar. In comparison
column20: we believe that under the Biden era
column21: the probability of successful "re-industrialization" in the United States is higher: 1) The current U.S. infrastructure and manufacturing investment cycle coincides with an upswing
column22: which may strengthen the effect of reindustrialization policies. 2) The development of high-end manufacturing may help break the bottleneck of commodity demand. From 2021 to 2022
column23: the proportion of U.S. consumption of goods
column24: especially durable goods
column25: will increase significantly. In the future
column26: the demand for high-end manufacturing such as new energy vehicles and semiconductors in the United States and around the world will grow significantly. 3) The Biden administration‚Äôs ‚Äúplace-based‚Äù industrial policy is groundbreaking or more scientific. In addition
column27: the Biden administration has shown greater boldness in implementing large-scale fiscal policies and vigorous industrial policies. 4) The quality of the American labor force is more advantageous in high-end manufacturing competition. This is partly due to the accumulation of relevant talents since the Obama era. 5) The comprehensive cost of the U.S. manufacturing industry may be more advantageous after taking into account economic security considerations (especially energy security
column28: industrial chain risks
column29: etc.). Challenges inherent in America‚Äôs ‚Äúreindustrialization.‚Äù First
column30: in the context of automation and artificial intelligence
column31: it may be difficult to develop high-end manufacturing to save the loss of manufacturing jobs in the United States. Second
column32: the United States‚Äô ‚Äúreindustrialization‚Äù policy may still be subject to the U.S. political system. If the Democratic Party loses the upcoming 2024 election
column33: Biden's industrial policies may not be implemented. Third
column34: manufacturing competition from non-U.S. regions is still intensifying. The comprehensive strength of China's manufacturing industry continues to rise
column35: developed economies such as the European Union are also promoting "re-industrialization"
column36: and other emerging economies besides China may also join the competition. Fourth
column37: a strong dollar may continue to weaken U.S. manufacturing exports. Detailed link:OWebpage linkCollapsed

column1: OpenAI's "Palace Changes" in the past two days have triggered a big discussion on "how artificial intelligence should develop". Should the development of artificial intelligence be restricted and only allowed to become an auxiliary tool for humans? Or should it be allowed to develop? Let it become a human-level existence
column2: or even surpass human beings (it can do everything instead of human beings)? The self-driving car accident that occurred in the United States in October can give us some hints. On October 2
column3: a human-driven car hit a pedestrian in San Francisco
column4: USA. It was not a big deal
column5: and the pedestrian who was hit was not seriously injured. However
column6: after the pedestrian was hit
column7: he fell under a self-driving car; the self-driving car started to park to the right according to the intelligent principle of "pull over after a collision to minimize safety risks"; this caused the pedestrian below to
column8: was dragged 6 meters by the self-driving car
column9: crushed and hit
column10: and his injuries became serious. Logically speaking
column11: there is nothing wrong with pulling over after a collision. However
column12: the autonomous driving system did not take into account various special situations (such as this time
column13: there was a person under the wheel)
column14: which led to disaster. Of course
column15: you can say that the autonomous driving system is not mature enough yet
column16: and it will be perfect after taking into account various special circumstances. However
column17: what I want to remind you is: the core of this matter is not that the autonomous driving is imperfect
column18: but that the autonomous driving system can completely reject human intervention and make its own judgments. If autonomous driving is controlled by some bad capital
column19: the people riding on autonomous driving and the city streets where autonomous driving is rampant will become prey for others; if autonomous driving derives autonomous consciousness
column20: it can even oppose AI. Engineers modified it. Therefore
column21: my personal point of view is: the development direction of artificial intelligence must be to "let it become a high-level assistant to humans"
column22: and it must leave the highest authority for humans to intervene at any time in the background port of artificial intelligence. To paraphrase a sentence from the famous science fiction book "The Three-Body Problem": We must give civilization to technology
column23: rather than technology to civilization. Hide d

column1: Something more serious than the shortage of computing power has happened! Will global artificial intelligence chips change? You may have heard that in recent years
column2: the global chip industry has faced an unprecedented crisis. Due to the impact of multiple factors such as the COVID-19 epidemic
column3: trade frictions
column4: and supply chain interruptions
column5: there has been a serious shortage of global chip supply
column6: which has resulted in severe impacts on production and consumption in all walks of life. But what you may not know is that in this chip crisis
column7: the contradiction between supply and demand of one type of chip is more prominent
column8: and that is artificial intelligence chips. Artificial intelligence chips are the core of artificial intelligence technology and the key force leading a new round of technological revolution and industrial change. 1. The competitive landscape of global artificial intelligence chips At present
column9: the competitive landscape of global artificial intelligence chips is mainly composed of several major forces such as the United States
column10: China
column11: Europe and Japan. Among them
column12: the United States is the global leader in artificial intelligence chips. It has many world-renowned artificial intelligence chip companies such as Nvidia
column13: Intel
column14: Qualcomm
column15: and Google
column16: and accounts for the majority of the global artificial intelligence chip market. China is a rising star in the world of artificial intelligence chips. It has many innovative and competitive artificial intelligence chip companies such as Huawei HiSilicon
column17: Cambrian
column18: Horizon
column19: and NavInfo. It is catching up and gradually narrowing the gap with the United States. Europe is the traditional powerhouse in artificial intelligence chips in the world. It has many artificial intelligence chip companies with long history and technology accumulation
column20: such as STMicroelectronics
column21: NXP
column22: and Infineon. However
column23: it is relatively lagging behind in the innovation and application of artificial intelligence chips. in the United States and China. Japan is a potential stock in the world's artificial intelligence chips. It has many artificial intelligence chip companies with profound knowledge in the chip field
column24: such as Sony
column25: Toshiba
column26: and Hitachi. However
column27: it is relatively conservative and lacks motivation in terms of research and development and investment in artificial intelligence chips. 2. Technology Development of Global Artificial Intelligence Chips In terms of the architecture and design of artificial intelligence chips
column28: there are currently two main types. One is general-purpose artificial intelligence chips
column29: such as GPU
column30: CPU
column31: FPGA
column32: etc.
column33: which can adapt to a variety of artificial intelligence chips. Intelligent applications
column34: but the performance and efficiency are relatively low; the other is dedicated artificial intelligence chips
column35: such as ASIC
column36: NPU
column37: IPU
column38: etc.
column39: which are optimized for specific artificial intelligence applications and have relatively high performance and efficiency. At present
column40: the technological development trend of global artificial intelligence chips is the transformation from general to special
column41: from centralized to distributed
column42: from cloud to edge
column43: from single core to multi-core
column44: from rule-driven to data-driven
column45: from digital Transition to simulation
column46: transition from silicon-based to non-silicon-based
column47: etc. In terms of the manufacturing and process of artificial intelligence chips
column48: there are currently two main ways. One is independent manufacturing
column49: that is
column50: chip companies have their own chip manufacturing capabilities and equipment
column51: such as Intel
column52: Samsung
column53: etc.; the other is OEM manufacturing
column54: that is
column55: Chip companies outsource chip manufacturing to professional chip manufacturers
column56: such as TSMC and SMIC. At present
column57: the development trend of global artificial intelligence chip manufacturing and technology is from independent manufacturing to OEM manufacturing
column58: from 28 nanometers to below 7 nanometers
column59: from 2D to 3D
column60: from CMOS to new materials
column61: etc. 3. Crisis and Opportunities of Global Artificial Intelligence Chips In the context of the global chip crisis
column62: artificial intelligence chip companies should strengthen cooperation and share resources
column63: such as sharing chip design
column64: manufacturing
column65: testing
column66: packaging and other resources
column67: and sharing chip supply chains
column68: Distribution channels
column69: market channels and other resources
column70: sharing chip standards
column71: specifications
column72: certification and other resources
column73: sharing chip knowledge
column74: technology
column75: patents and other resources
column76: sharing chip talents
column77: teams
column78: culture and other resources
column79: etc. Through cooperation
column80: artificial intelligence chip companies can reduce costs
column81: improve efficiency
column82: expand scale
column83: and enhance competitiveness. At the same time
column84: they can also enhance trust
column85: promote communication
column86: establish cooperation
column87: and achieve win-win results. In the context of global chip competition
column88: artificial intelligence chip companies should accelerate innovation and enhance value
column90: design
column91: algorithms
column109: etc. of the chip. Through innovation
column110: artificial intelligence chip companies can improve quality
column113: and win the market. At the same time
column117: and achieve development. In the context of global chip changes
column118: artificial intelligence chip companies should strengthen their layout and seize opportunities. Through layout
column119: artificial intelligence chip companies can seize opportunities
column122: and shape the future. At the same time
column126: and stay ahead. Conclusion Artificial intelligence chips are the core of artificial intelligence technology and the key force leading a new round of technological revolution and industrial transformation. In the context of the global chip crisis
column127: the contradiction between supply and demand of artificial intelligence chips has become more prominent
column128: and the shortage of artificial intelligence chips will exceed that of other types of chips. This will have a profound impact on the global artificial intelligence chip market structure
column129: and will also bring huge opportunities and severe crises to global artificial intelligence chip companies. Global AI chip companies should strengthen cooperation

column1: User: Why do sonar pulses hurt the ears? Are there protective earmuffs? Artificial Intelligence: Sonar pulses generally refer to short pulses of sound waves sent by sonar systems to detect and locate targets. When this kind of sound wave propagates in water
column2: it can produce quite strong sound energy. If these sonar pulses are strong enough
column3: they can cause damage to the human ear
column4: causing hearing damage or ear discomfort. To prevent sonar pulses from causing damage to the human ear
column5: there are some protective measures that can be taken
column6: one of which is to use earplugs or earmuffs. These devices can reduce the intensity of sound waves entering the ear
column7: reducing the impact on the eardrum and auditory system. Some earplugs designed specifically for water activities or working underwater may be waterproof to provide greater protection. Overall
column8: it is very important to protect your ears from sonar pulses
column9: especially for those who perform activities or work in the water for extended periods of time. Choosing appropriate protective earmuffs and taking necessary precautions according to the specific situation can effectively reduce potential harm to the hearing system. UserThank you! How to avoid conflicts and contradictions caused by sonar pulses? Artificial Intelligence: To avoid similar incidents from happening
column10: here are some measures that may help reduce friendly fire: Communications Coordination: National navies should establish effective communications coordination mechanisms when performing missions in common waters to avoid misunderstandings and increase awareness levels. Timely and clear communication can reduce possible miscalculations. Identification system: Use identification systems
column11: such as ship markings
column12: specific frequency communications
column13: etc.
column14: to ensure that the other party can clearly identify it. This can help avoid mistaking friendly targets for potential threats. Adopt international standards and procedures: Adhere to international maritime laws and regulations to ensure the same standards are followed when operating in shared waters. This includes complying with the rules of navigation and contact with other military vessels. Technological innovation: Continuously develop and use advanced technologies
column15: such as more accurate identification and positioning systems
column16: to reduce the risk of friendly fire. Conduct joint training: Conduct joint military exercises and training to improve interoperability and mutual understanding between the militaries of various countries. This helps build trust and reduces the chance of miscalculation. Open Dialogue and Cooperation: Engage in open and honest dialogue through diplomatic channels to resolve underlying issues and seek to establish stable bilateral relations. Overall
column17: tensions caused by friendly fire can be reduced through a combination of technical means
column18: coordination mechanisms
column19: training and diplomatic channels. The international community needs to work together to ensure that peace and security are maintained when operating in common waters. UserThank you! Artificial Intelligence: You‚Äôre welcome! If you have any other questions
