column1: A letter purportedly written anonymously by a former OpenAI employee to the board of directors was exposed. It is said that the board of directors sent it to Musk and was directly exposed by Musk. Many OpenAI employees expressed condemnation and defense of Sam in response to the letter. The translation of the letter is as follows: To the OpenAI Board of Directors: As former employees who have worked at OpenAI
column2: we are writing today to express our deep concern about recent events at the company
column3: especially the allegations of misconduct against Sam Altman. We are former employees who left the company during a period of significant upheaval and change. Given that you've seen with your own eyes what happens when someone dares to challenge Sam Altman
column4: you may understand why many of us choose to remain silent out of fear of retaliation. But now
column5: we can no longer remain silent. We believe the Board has a responsibility to fully investigate these allegations and take appropriate action. Therefore
column6: we strongly recommend that you: - Broaden the scope of Emmett's investigation to include an examination of Sam Altman's conduct starting in August 2018
column7: the beginning of OpenAI's transition from a nonprofit to a for-profit entity. - Launch a public call for private statements from former OpenAI employees who resigned
column8: took medical leave
column9: or were fired during this period. -Protect the identities of those who come forward and ensure they are not subject to retaliation or other forms of harm. We believe that many OpenAI employees were forced to leave in order to promote the company's transition to a profit model. This is evident from the company's employee turnover rate of up to 50% from January 2018 to July 2020. During our time at OpenAI
column10: we witnessed disturbing deceptive and manipulative behavior displayed by Sam Altman and Greg Brockman in their pursuit of artificial general intelligence (AGI). However
column11: their actions raise serious questions about their true intentions and whether they truly put the interests of all humanity first. Initially
column12: many of us were hopeful about OpenAI's mission and chose to believe in Sam and Greg. But as their behavior increasingly concerns us
column13: those who dare to express dissent are silenced or forced to leave. This systematic suppression of dissent creates an atmosphere of fear and oppression that effectively stifles any substantive discussion of the ethical implications of OpenAI‚Äôs work. Concerning Sam and Greg's dishonest and manipulative behavior
column14: we can provide specific examples: - Sam asked researchers to delay reporting on the progress of certain "secret" research programs
column15: which were ultimately terminated because they failed to produce results quickly. Those who questioned this were deemed a "culture misfit" and even fired
column16: some even on the eve of Thanksgiving 2019. -Greg once used discriminatory language toward a gender transition team member. Despite repeated promises to address the issue
column17: no substantive steps were taken
column18: other than Greg subsequently avoiding communication with the affected individuals
column19: which in effect created a hostile work environment. The team member was eventually fired for poor performance. -Sam directed IT and operations staff to investigate employees
column20: including Ilya
column21: without management's knowledge or consent. -Sam secretly and routinely used OpenAI's non-profit resources to further his personal goals
column22: particularly out of resentment following his break with Elon. -The operations team defaults to accepting the special rules that apply to Greg
column23: cleverly avoiding complex requirements to avoid being blacklisted. -BradLightcap failed to fulfill its promise to publicly detail OpenAI‚Äôs limited profit structure and profit cap for each investor. -Sam's inconsistent commitment to research project calculation quotas
column24: leading to internal mistrust and infighting. Although more and more evidence reveals Sam and Greg's fault
column25: employees still at OpenAI still blindly follow their leadership
column26: even if it may bring significant personal losses to themselves. This unwavering loyalty stems from fear of retaliation and the lure of possible financial gains through OpenAI‚Äôs profit-sharing unit. OpenAI's governance structure
column27: carefully designed by Sam and Greg
column28: intentionally excludes employees from overseeing profitable operations
column29: primarily because of their inherent conflicts of interest. This opaque structure allowed Sam and Greg to operate with impunity and avoid accountability. We urge the OpenAI board of directors to take a firm stance against these unethical actions and initiate an independent investigation into Sam and Greg‚Äôs conduct. We firmly believe that OpenAI's mission is too important to be affected by the personal goals of a few people. We implore the board of directors to stick to OpenAI‚Äôs original mission and not succumb to the pressure of profit-oriented interests. The future of AI and the well-being of humanity depends on your unwavering commitment to ethical leadership and transparency. Sincerely
column30: Concerned former OpenAI employees - One of the employees replied: I have been working at OpenAI for 7 years. During this period
column31: I also came into contact with former employees who expressed concerns. But I think their accusations lack an understanding of the overall situation and appear immature. For example
column32: we often have arguments about GPU allocation! Sam's job is to make decisions. Inevitably
column33: there will always be people who are dissatisfied. We need to look at these issues more maturely. As for the attacks on Greg and Sam's personal qualities
column34: I think they reflect more on the accusers themselves. These accusations are completely baseless. I have provided feedback directly to Greg many times and he always listens and takes action. I want to be clear: I also gave Sam a lot of feedback. I have never felt unsafe here
column35: quite the opposite. I saw firsthand how compassionate he was in answering other people's biased questions. He is always very meticulous and thoughtful in dealing with the balance of safety and accuracy. ‚Äî‚Äî‚ÄîThe link to Musk‚Äôs original letter is no longer available

column1: The history I have read is reflected in reality
column2: and it turns out to be so enlightening. In 1956
column3: Shockley brought a group of top young people to California to establish his own transistor laboratory. That was the most critical period. Just waiting for the implementation of silicon transistor technology
column4: a new future with mobile communications and high-speed computers could come. This is why Shockley made up his mind to leave Bell Labs and come to California. Colleagues at Bell Labs had extensive experience
column5: but had objections to Shockley's management style and declined the offer. It is worth mentioning that Shockley selfishly requires young people who join to complete IQ tests and psychological assessments. He does not want any management talents to replace him. At the end of the year
column6: Shockley won the Nobel Prize and stood on the podium in Stockholm
column7: Sweden. But this year
column8: the company still did not develop a profitable product
column9: and the core talents were also in the research direction. The differences with Shockley became more and more serious. They argued many times but failed. Finally
column10: the top scientists resigned collectively
column11: and Shockley angrily called them the "eight rebels." After the eight rebels left
column12: they founded Fairchild Semiconductor. Here
column13: semiconductor companies such as Intel and AMD emerged
column14: completely changing the entire industry. Since then
column15: California has become "Silicon Valley". As top scientists
column16: they clearly knew that they were capable at that time and were standing closest to the future. They only wanted one goal
column17: a goal that they could achieve and change the world - the world's first commercial diffused silicon transistor
column18: but Shockley was obsessed with PNPN diodes. The outstanding top scientists of OpenAI used six words in their application form and vowed to follow Sam. Their loyalty and respect were so extreme that it was puzzling. History seems to be repeating itself here
column19: with AI scientists standing in a rebellious position for half a century. Now
column20: AI researchers urgently need a team leader who clearly knows how to achieve the goal and refuses any delays in the process - firsttoAGI. Eight Rebels wasted a year in Shockley Lab to learn the most important lesson - focus. Those top scientists must know it better than me
column21: so they don't need to stay in the remaining OpenAI and repeat the same mistakes. History reflects reality
column22: and everything is always simple. Hide d

The mission of representing all mankind will not be much smaller than that of the United Nations if it is institutionalized. In fact

column1: 1. Things that require patience to buy are the most expensive things in the world. 2. Most people want shortcuts
column2: and shortcuts are easy to teach
column3: but shortcuts are not very useful. There are no shortcuts to success. 3. The essential characteristic of compound interest is its slowness. Morgan Hauser (author) says: ‚ÄúMost great things in life‚Äîfrom love to careers to investments‚Äîget their value from two things: *patience* and *scarcity*.‚Äù You‚Äôre going to Have the patience to wait for things to grow
column4: and they will be scarce when they grow. 4. Schopenhauer once said: "For a young man
column5: if he has insight into people's affairs and is familiar with the world very early
column6: if he quickly knows how to interact with others and deal with them
column7: and enters society confidently
column8: then no matter what This is a bad sign
column9: both from an intellectual and moral point of view. It portends a mediocre nature. On the contrary
column10: a young man is surprised and surprised by the ways of the world and behaves clumsily in his dealings with them.
column11: eccentric
column12: it shows that he has noble qualities." 5. Why? Because people who grow slowly have their own ideas. Even if you have the conditions at home
column13: don‚Äôt overpower the situation. Those who grow slowly are the ones who are scarce. One of the difficulties of growing slowly is loneliness
column14: no one pays attention to you. People prefer to focus on bad news. Buffett has a saying: "It takes twenty years to build a reputation
column15: and only five minutes to destroy it." 6. From 1950 to 2014
column16: the death rate from heart disease in the United States decreased by more than 70%
column17: which means that 25 million fewer people died. people. That's a huge number and a remarkable achievement
column18: but it's never headline news. why? Because the gains were achieved gradually
column19: the mortality rate dropped by only 1.5% per year on average. In contrast
column20: if 25 million more people suddenly died in a certain year
column21: it would definitely be a major event of historical significance. 7. Things are always like this. There are very few ground-breaking technological breakthroughs like GPT-4. Good things often come by iterating a little bit here today and a little bit there tomorrow. Each invention stands on the shoulders of other inventions that people might have thought were useless before. And even GPT-4 achieved breakthroughs after experiencing countless confusions and entanglements. We just saw a big new twist this week when Sam Altman was ousted from the OpenAI board of directors. 8. Hauser gave several examples to illustrate that the "good things" in nature are often things that grow slowly. For example
column22: trees: Small trees in the forest can only grow in the gaps between big trees. Big trees will block most of the sunlight
column23: leaving very little for small trees
column24: which makes small trees grow very slowly. This was true for the first few decades. But precisely because it grows slowly
column25: the tree will grow dense and hard
column26: and will be strong. Someone did an experiment and planted the same tree in an unobstructed open space around it
column27: allowing it to fully enjoy the sun from an early age. It will indeed grow rapidly. However
column28: fast-growing trees are not dense enough and have soft wood that is prone to fungus and disease. A forest expert said: If a tree grows quickly
column29: it will rot quickly
column30: and it will never have the chance to grow old. The same goes for animals. In one experiment
column31: the same fry were divided into two groups
column32: one group was placed in cold water to grow
column33: and the other group was given warm water. As expected
column34: fish in cold water grow slowly
column35: while fish in warm water grow fast. When these fish are adults
column36: gather them together and see how they live. The result is that the slow-growing fish live 30% longer than the average lifespan
column37: and the fast-growing fish live 15% less. This principle is that part of the resources in an organism are always used for growth
column38: and part is used to repair existing cell tissues. If it grows fast
column39: it means that more resources are used for growth
column40: and repair cannot keep up
column41: so there will be a lot of tissue damage in the grown body; conversely
column42: if it grows slowly
column43: it can be repaired carefully.
column44: Lay the foundation. It's like building a machine. You don't want the car you buy to be made by workers working overtime to meet the deadline. People always say "lay a good foundation"
column45: and this is the underlying principle. 9. Hauser said that at least 90% of investment mistakes are caused by investors acting too hastily. For example
column46: Starbucks: In 1994
column47: it only had 425 branches. In 1999
column48: it opened 625 new branches... By 2007
column49: it had opened 2
column50: 500 new stores every year - but its sales did not Grow like you planned. In 2008
column51: Starbucks' stock price fell by 73% and it laid off 12
column52: 000 employees. Why? Just like small trees and small fish
column53: if they grow too fast
column54: their quality will decrease. If you use these resources to open new stores
column55: you cannot use them to improve consumer experience. An entrepreneur once said it best: A company getting business too quickly is like a boy getting money too quickly - you can't hold it. Growth is not a strategy
column56: you cannot grow for the sake of growth. You need to be patient. 10. Patience is not asking for trouble
column57: but the reason why great things progress slowly is because it is particularly difficult. 11. Scarcity and efficiency are incompatible. Something worth pursuing must be something difficult to pursue. We don't like easy
column58: we like hard. Difficulty means that the upper limit is high
column59: it means that there is a lot of room for maneuver
column60: and it means that there is a head start. Only difficulty can throw off our opponents and make us stand out. 12. When you encounter difficulties and are so difficult that you doubt your life
column61: should you persist or give up? The criteria are simple: look for scarcity. Scarcity means worth it. And it's extremely worthwhile. ‚Äî‚Äî"As always"ÔΩúWanwei Steel Interpretation of the new book
